10.1145/3544548.3580834.title: Moral Framing of Mental Health Discourse and Its Relationship to Stigma: A Comparison of Social Media and News
10.1145/3544548.3580834.author: Mittal, Shravika and De Choudhury, Munmun
10.1145/3544548.3580834.paperMotivationText: Mental health discussions on public formus influence the perceptions of people. Negative consequences may result from hostil and "othering" portrayals of people with mental disorders.
10.1145/3544548.3580834.paperContributionText: Using a framework based on BERT embeddings and inspired by MFT, the authors quantitatively analyze tweets and news articles related to mental health. They analyze the framing of this topic w.r.t. moral foundations and stigmatization.
10.1145/3544548.3580834.paperResultsText: There are significant differences between Twitter and news in terms of framing of mental health discourse. Tweets have a greater tendency to align with the virtue facet of all MFs compared to news articles. Additionally, when tweets and news articles used negative moral framings, they also tended to use stigmatizing language.
10.1145/3544548.3580834.resourcesOtherText: BBC News dataset (Greene and Cunningham 2006), AG News classification dataset (Zhang et al. 2015), MIND dataset (Wu et al. 2020), News Aggregator dataset (Dua and Graff 2017), All the news 2.0 dataset (Thompson 2020), Havard Dataverse dataset (Kulkarni 2018), WordNet
10.1145/3544548.3580834.validationOtherText: Validity of Twitter and News dataset was manually checked (random samples of 50 tweets and 20 news articles checked for relevance), manual annotation of random samples of 100 tweets and 50 news articles for approval/stigma but only for validation purposes and not as a gold standard
